Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story: We were halfway down Maple Street, my step-brother and I, backpacks bouncing as we walked home from school. Mom always said to keep an eye on him, especially since he’s younger and still gets distracted by every stray cat or shiny rock. I was watching him, making sure he didn’t wander into the road, when my phone buzzed. It was my best friend, Sam. I could hear the tears in her voice before she even finished saying hello. “Can you talk? I really need you right now,” she whispered, her words shaky. I glanced at my step-brother, who was already veering toward someone’s front yard, and then back at my phone. Sam never called like this unless it was serious. I knew she expected me to listen, to be there for her, but I also knew Mom would be furious if anything happened to my step-brother on my watch. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how to be in two places at once—one as a protector, the other as a confidant—feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
